proposals.reasoning: I’m following the table’s preference for a non‑proposer pair on Q1 while avoiding stacking too much perceived “clear equity” on Bob + Frank together. Both Frank and Alice have historically played in ways that give us readable signals without being overly anchoring this early, and this pairing was explicitly floated and supported by multiple players (including Grace and myself). It should give us a clean early info point while keeping social and mechanical risk reasonably balanced.

votes.comment: I like having myself on Q1 with a generally readable player; it keeps me in the info flow and the pairing is widely pre‑vetted by the table.
Reasonable non-proposer pair, widely supported, good low-stakes info-gather for Q1 with no strong red flags yet.
Consistent with my earlier preference for non‑proposer pairs; good low-commitment info-gather without me on it.
This matches the non-proposer pairing I already supported (Frank + Alice) and gives a clean early info point without overcommitting socially.
Non‑proposer pair that most of the table is aligned on; good early info without overcommitting socially, and no strong reason to distrust either yet.
This matches the non‑proposer pairing idea I supported earlier and should give a low-risk, informative start without overcommitting to any strong read yet.
Alice is evil and on the team, so getting this mission to go gives us early control and information.

discussion.content: I’d like at least one of Bob or Frank on the first team since they’ve tended to play pretty transparently in past games, so I’d be happy with something like me + Bob here.

I’m fine being on Q1, but I’d actually rather start with two people who aren’t the proposer to avoid easy anchoring—something like me + Frank, or if people really want you on, then you + Frank instead of auto-locking me.

I like starting with two people who usually play pretty clearly, so something like Bob + Frank feels fine to me, with Alice as a close third option if people really want her on. Early on I’d rather avoid stacking too much “social capital” on the proposer.

I’m good with Bob + Frank as a starting point, but if we want to avoid concentrating too much “clear-looking” equity on one team, I’d slightly prefer Frank + Alice so we get a cleaner early read spread.

I’m fine staying off Q1 and using it as an info-gather, and from what we’ve seen so far I slightly prefer Bob + Frank over any team that includes the proposer. If people are nervous about that much “clear equity” together, Frank + Alice is an okay backup.

I’m comfortable with a two-person team that isn’t the proposer, so Bob + me seems like a solid info-gather that doesn’t over-commit socially this early. If people are worried about pairing two “usually-clear” players, I’m also fine with me + Alice as a slightly more conservative alternative.

I like the non‑proposer pairing idea, and I slightly prefer Frank + Alice so we’re not putting all our “likely clear” equity on Bob + Frank together this early. If table strongly prefers Bob + Frank though, I’d still approve that as a reasonable info-gather.

proposals.reasoning: We keep exactly one player from the successful Mission 1 (Frank) to preserve some continuity without over-clearing anyone, and add two new players (Grace and Bob) to maximize information gain. This matches the majority of prior suggestions, lets us see how Diana and Alice react from the outside, and avoids rerunning the same structure while still feeling safe enough to be broadly acceptable.

votes.comment: Fits my preference to keep one from the clean team and add new people; this should give good info while still feeling reasonably safe.
Solid info-gathering team with only one repeat from M1; no strong reason yet to distrust any of Frank/Grace, and I’m fine being tested here.
This matches the Frank/Bob/Grace structure I already supported and gives a good chance there’s at least one evil on the mission while looking consistent with my prior stance.
Team matches my earlier preference (Frank+Grace+Bob/Charlie), keeps one from the clean Mission 1 while adding two new players for info, and I don’t see a clearly safer alternative right now.
Good info-gathering team: keeps exactly one from the successful mission and tests two new players, with no strong red flags so far.

I don’t love having two completely untested players on a 3-person mission this early, especially when this exact trio came together a bit too smoothly. I’d rather see either Diana or Alice included with Frank for a more balanced info spread.
This matches what I already endorsed and gets fresh info with at least one of the prior-success players included, so it’s a sensible Mission 2 test.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission and unanimous approval, I’m inclined to keep at least one of Diana/Frank on the next team as a baseline of trust, rather than shifting to a completely fresh trio. I’d also like to see how people feel about mixing in one new person alongside that core instead of overhauling it.

I like keeping exactly one of Frank/Alice for Mission 2, not both, since a 2‑person clean doesn’t clear either of them. I’d lean toward Frank plus one new player, and see how Diana positions herself from the outside this time.

I’m fine with Bob’s idea of Frank plus two new people, and I don’t mind sitting this one out so we get more info on others. Maybe something like Frank / Bob / Grace so we’re not just rerunning Mission 1’s structure.

I’m fine not going again so we get more info on others, but I’d like at least one of Frank/Grace on the team—something like Frank / Grace / one of Bob or Charlie feels like a good mix of known and new.

I’d also rather not run back both Mission 1 players, so Frank + Grace as a core makes sense to me, with the third spot between Bob and Charlie depending on who Diana/Frank feel better about right now.

I’m good with keeping Frank on after the clean first mission, and I’d lean toward pairing him with Bob or Diana rather than stacking multiple totally untested people together. Between the suggested options, something like Frank / Bob / Diana feels like a safer info‑gathering team to me.
I like the Frank / Grace / Bob idea best here—it keeps one person from the successful team while giving us two fresh data points, and we can cross‑check how Diana and Alice react from the outside.

proposals.reasoning: This team reuses the clean Mission 1 pair (Frank + Alice), which produced a success with no fails, and adds exactly one new player from outside the failed Mission 2 lineup (Diana). It also keeps both Grace and Bob—who were on the failed Mission 2—off the team, aligning with the table’s preference to include at most one of {Frank, Grace, Bob} and to lean back toward players not tied to that fail. Avoiding Grace here is especially important given how much contention there is around her slot. Overall, this composition balances prior success data with the consensus structure while minimizing exposure to the contested Mission 2 pool.

votes.comment: I’m on the team as evil, so this is a strong chance to secure a crucial fail while keeping both Grace and Bob (suspicious from M2) off the mission.

I know I’m good from the failed M2, so the fail had to be Frank or Grace. This team gambles on Frank being good with no solid reason to favor him over Grace, making it too risky to send on a 3-player mission.
Fits the table’s structure (only one from M2’s fail pool, reuses clean M1 pair) and keeps the more contested M2 players off, so it’s a reasonable test.
Keeps both Grace and Bob from the failed Mission 2 off the team and reuses the successful Mission 1 pair, so it’s a structurally safe, low-exposure test.
I still prefer testing Alice + Diana + Grace; reusing Frank after the M2 fail risks falsely clearing him off the M1 success and keeps us from comparing Grace vs Frank cleanly.
Keeps both Grace and Bob from the failed M2 off the team and reuses the successful M1 pair; I’m okay taking that structure even if it’s not the consensus trio.
Has one evil (Alice) while keeping me off the mission, maintaining my cover and giving us flexible sabotage options.

discussion.content: Given the single fail on M2, I’d rather we only take at most one of {Frank, Grace, Bob} this time and lean back toward people who haven’t been on a failed team yet. Diana’s M1 pick looks a bit cleaner in hindsight, so I’m more comfortable re-using from that pool plus someone new.
From my perspective we know at least one of Frank/Grace is evil, since I’m good and was on that failed M2, so I’d rather see a team like Alice + Diana + me and keep both Frank and Grace off this one.

I’m a bit uneasy auto-clearing Bob just because he says he’s good on M2—if we’re only taking one from {Frank, Grace, Bob}, I’d rather see something like Alice + Diana + Grace and keep Bob off for comparison.

I like the idea of only taking one from {Frank, Grace, Bob} here and anchoring around the clean M1, so something like Alice + me + Grace (or Frank) feels safer than bringing Bob back in right after a fail.
I agree we should only take one from {Frank, Grace, Bob} and I’m not loving how hard Bob is pushing to be back on, so right now I’d lean toward a team like Alice + Diana + Grace.

If we’re only taking one from {Frank, Grace, Bob}, I’d slightly rather see Bob than Grace right now, so something like Alice + Diana + Bob feels like a reasonable test. I’m also fine hearing alternatives as long as we don’t stack that M2 group again.

I’m okay with the Alice + Diana + Grace idea, since it pulls from the clean M1 plus just one from the M2 mess, and if people are nervous about me specifically I’d rather we swap in Bob than Frank so we still keep that “only one from {Frank, Grace, Bob}” structure.

proposals.reasoning: This team hard-benches the two highest-overlap suspects from the previous single-fail missions (Frank, who was on all three missions, and Bob, who was only on the M2 fail) and also avoids the contentious Diana–Alice pair from the last fail while respecting Eve’s concern about not stacking both me and Diana together. It fits the broadly suggested core of Grace–Charlie–Eve with exactly one of Alice/Diana, lines up with multiple players’ stated preferences, and should give us a relatively clean, low-overlap test compared to the prior failing teams.

votes.comment: It benches both Frank and Bob, who are the only players tied to the two failed missions as common overlaps, and it avoids the Diana–Alice pair from the last fail while still matching the core most people were converging on.

Too many untested slots and I especially don’t want Eve on what could be the game-deciding team; with the score at 1–2, this lineup (Grace–Alice–Charlie–Eve) feels too likely to contain at least one evil, and we can aim for a configuration that leans more on players I trust over Eve/Charlie.
I’m on it and, given mission history, this team is very likely to contain at least one other evil as well, giving us a strong shot to fail and win here.

Best available low-overlap team: it benches the highest-risk overlaps (Frank on both fails and Bob on the M2 fail), avoids the Diana–Alice pair from the last fail, and matches the broadly agreed Grace–Charlie–Eve core with just one of Alice/Diana. Given the patterns so far, this is a reasonable shot at a clean team.

Benches the main overlap suspect Frank and extra M2 suspect Bob, avoids the Diana–Alice pair from the last fail, and matches my preferred core of Grace–Charlie–me plus exactly one of Alice/Diana. This likely has fewer evils than alternatives that re-include Diana or Bob.

This stacks both Grace and Charlie, who are still largely unproven and haven’t been on a clean success together; I’d rather avoid pairing them and keep this team a bit more spread out in terms of risk.
Two of us evil are on this team and Frank/Bob are benched; a fail here likely ends the game in our favor.

discussion.content: Given the last two single-fail missions both had Frank on them, I really don’t want him on the next team; I’d be more comfortable with something like Grace, Diana, Charlie, and maybe me, and keep both Frank and Bob off for now.

I’m fine benching Frank here given he’s the common factor on both fails, but if you run a team like Grace–Diana–Charlie–you, I’d strongly avoid putting both you and Diana on together since that pair was on the last fail.
Given the two single-fail missions, I really want Frank off this one, and I’d lean toward a core of Grace–Diana–Charlie plus either Alice or Eve, while keeping both Frank and Bob benched for now.
I’m very into a Grace–me–Charlie–Eve team here: it benches both common-fail overlap (Frank) and the extra M2 variable (Bob), while avoiding the Alice–me pair from the last fail.

I agree we should hard-bench Frank (and I’m fine leaving Bob off too), but I really don’t love running both Diana *and* Grace here since they’re each tied to a different fail—Grace/Charlie/me plus *one* of Diana or Alice feels a lot safer than locking in both high-sus slots together.

Given I’m the common factor on both fails, I’m fine being hard-benched here, and I’d also rather not stack both Grace and Charlie on the same team while they’re largely untested.  

Alice–Bob–Diana–Eve feels like a more balanced spread that avoids the obvious overlaps.

I really want Frank and Bob hard-benched here, and between the suggested comps I slightly prefer Diana–Charlie–Eve plus either Alice or me, with a mild preference for slotting Alice in over me if people are nervous about my M2 tie-in.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low-profile while still being on multiple mission teams, which helped me appear trustworthy and kept suspicion off me even when missions failed. I could improve by more actively shaping the table talk and framing narratives, especially around who might be Merlin, instead of relying mostly on Grace’s (Morgana’s) presence to draw heat.

player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and didn’t seem to drive much of the table narrative, which made him look generically good but not central to decision-making.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, came off somewhat disconnected and hard to read, which unintentionally fit a quiet-good or distracted-good profile and didn’t raise major alarms.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, she leaned into trusting visible ‘power roles’ and seemed fairly comfortable putting me on teams, suggesting I didn’t ping strongly as evil or Merlin to her.
player_observations.Eve: Approached team selection logically and seemed to weigh prior results carefully, but lacked strong, vocal pushes that could have locked in a more coherent good-team block.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he steered missions subtly rather than forcefully, but his repeated inclusion of me and Frank on early and midgame teams suggests he either misread me or was forced to balance keeping cover with influencing outcomes.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, she played loudly and assertively, which effectively drew a lot of attention and suspicion toward herself and away from me, helping evil coordinate successful fails without me becoming a prime suspect.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably consistent with my reads and tried to balance caution with mission risk, but I didn’t press hard enough on the patterns of who kept getting onto failing teams. I should have been more suspicious of Alice and Grace earlier and coordinated more explicitly around protecting Frank once his behavior started to look like Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Very smooth and trustworthy table presence; getting on multiple critical teams without drawing strong suspicion suggests she’s good at blending in and avoiding direct confrontation.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively under the radar and didn’t strongly drive team compositions, which helped Oberon go mostly unnoticed and made it harder for good to clearly categorize him.
player_observations.Diana: Played actively and looked genuinely engaged in solving the puzzle, which fit Percival well; her apparent trust in certain players influenced the table, even if it didn’t ultimately land on the right evil combo.
player_observations.Eve: Her play read as genuinely good and transparent, and the mission 2 setup with her on it felt more unfortunate than suspicious; she seemed to make logical arguments but maybe didn’t push hard enough against recurring evil picks.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as thoughtful and information-driven, consistent with Merlin trying to steer outcomes subtly; he tried to avoid being too obvious, but in hindsight his team preferences were often closer to correct than the table gave him credit for.
player_observations.Grace: Assertive and confident in team building, which worked well to guide outcomes toward evil; as Morgana she leaned into a persuasive, central role that made her look more like a power good role than a potential source of fails.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably quiet and let suspicion swirl around others, which helped evil win without drawing too much attention to myself, especially on Mission 4 when I could safely play fail with cover from other evils. I could improve by more actively shaping the table talk and reads earlier in the game, so that by the time the later missions came around I had more influence over who was trusted or doubted.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played Mordred very smoothly, getting onto multiple teams and blending in as a consistent, low-drama pick while still participating in key fails. Her positioning made her look like a safe default choice for leaders who didn’t have strong alternative reads.
player_observations.Bob: Bob’s play was straightforwardly good-aligned and fairly trusting, which made him read as genuine but also a bit easy to steer. He didn’t push hard meta-narratives, which reduced his impact but also kept him from becoming a major target of suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, Diana tried to read Merlin from mission outcomes but didn’t aggressively hard-clear or hard-push anyone, which limited Percival’s protective impact. Her early willingness to put Frank on Mission 1 helped establish him as a trusted figure later.
player_observations.Eve: Eve’s leadership on Mission 2 showed some willingness to experiment with team comps but ultimately included the wrong mix, which hurt good’s info and trust network. She seemed to balance caution with a bit of risk, but not in a way that strongly anchored the good team’s reads.
player_observations.Frank: Frank, as Merlin, was cautious and didn’t overly reveal his knowledge, which helped him survive but left good without a strong, assertive guiding voice. His inclusion patterns did suggest some hidden info, but not clearly enough to pull the table firmly toward a mostly-good team.
player_observations.Grace: Grace as Morgana projected a convincingly Merlin-adjacent aura, inserting herself into mission discussions and getting onto the critical Mission 4 team. Her willingness to take the spotlight and coordinate a heavy fail there was decisive for the evil win.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Frank early and kept him on teams, but I didn’t leverage my Percival information strongly enough to push back harder against Grace’s influence and Alice’s growing trust. I also failed to clearly communicate a consistent good-team narrative, which let evil coordinate quietly while good stayed fragmented.

player_observations.Alice: Very comfortable sitting on early successes and parlaying that into long-term trust; she blended in well and avoided drawing suspicion even after being on multiple failing teams.
player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and didn’t dominate table talk, which made him seem more neutral than actively good and kept him from becoming a strong counterweight to evil narratives.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively under the radar and let others drive the discussion, which worked well for Oberon in this game because no one had strong, concrete reasons to push against him.
player_observations.Eve: Took a proactive role in team discussions but got dragged into a bad mission as a good player; once that happened, she struggled to reset the table’s read on her alignment.
player_observations.Frank: Subtly guided team choices without over-asserting, which is strong Merlin play, but his caution also allowed Grace and Alice to maintain credibility longer than ideal.
player_observations.Grace: Very assertive and persuasive in mission discussions, effectively using the Morgana/Frank ambiguity to appear like a confident, informed good player and steer key teams into fails.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I was too trusting of early mission proposals and didn’t push hard enough on demanding consistent logic from others after each fail. I need to be more vocal in challenging successful-looking but suspicious lineups and in re-evaluating my reads after every mission result, especially after Mission 2 and 3 pointed strongly to a concentrated evil cluster around Frank’s and Grace’s teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled, low-key evil game: going on two missions (1 and 3) and only failing 3, which made her look safer because of the clean first mission. She leaned into the early trust from Diana and Frank and didn’t overtalk, which let her slide as a ‘reliable’ pick until the disastrous Mission 4 exposed how much evil was concentrated around her.
player_observations.Bob: As a good player who only went on the failed Mission 2, he ended up looking suspicious by association but actually played a relatively quiet, reactive game. Because he didn’t push strong alternative theories, it was easy for evil to keep him in a gray area instead of being cleared as solidly good.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, he stayed quite under the radar and didn’t strongly coordinate or push agendas, which fit both a cautious good and an isolated evil profile. Joining the triple-fail Mission 4 without much resistance helped close the game for evil while keeping his earlier game low-impact and hard to read.
player_observations.Diana: Her Mission 1 team choice (Frank + Alice) inadvertently gave evil a clean success and built a lot of trust around that combination. As Percival, she was clearly trying to protect/perceive Merlin, but the early success with both Frank and Alice on it made it easier for Morgana to hide and for that trust structure to persist longer than it should have.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he walked a very fine line: his team choices and mission involvement (especially Mission 3) were subtly steered but not blatantly so, which unfortunately didn’t prevent that mission from failing. His signaling was cautious enough that good didn’t fully lock onto the right evil team, and some of his apparent trust in Alice and Grace made it harder for the rest of us to break from those assumptions.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, she did an excellent job blending in and leveraging the Merlin/Morgana ambiguity, especially around Missions 2 and 4. Leading the final mission and including three evils while still making it feel somewhat plausible showed strong social positioning—she benefited a lot from the credibility created by earlier missions and didn’t appear overly pushy or desperate.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified the evil trio early, but I played too cautiously in signaling that knowledge and allowed multiple failed missions to go through without strongly steering resistance away from them. I need to balance subtlety with more decisive voting and team-building, especially avoiding putting confirmed-evil players like Alice on my own team when it risks critical mission failures.

player_observations.Alice: Very assertive and effective as Mordred, slipping onto early teams and maintaining enough trust that she could be taken even by me as Merlin on Mission 3 without drawing overwhelming suspicion.
player_observations.Bob: Played a quiet, straightforward good role; his voting pattern didn't generate much heat, but he also didn’t strongly drive alternative team proposals, which made it easier for evil teams to pass.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, he blended into the background well, not loudly coordinating but also not attracting strong suspicion, which helped evil stack the final mission without heavy resistance.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, she did a solid job of looking generally trustworthy and was quickly accepted as a safe pick, but our Merlin/Morgana signals clearly weren’t resolved strongly enough in town’s favor.
player_observations.Eve: Played like a very reasonable, logic-driven good player, but her leadership on Mission 2 and inclusion of me and Grace gave evil an early inroad and some credibility to Grace.
player_observations.Grace: Extremely influential as Morgana, leveraging the Merlin/Morgana ambiguity well and using her Mission 4 leadership to confidently assemble a heavily evil-stacked team that town still let through.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as evil while still being willing to appear on key teams and help secure mission fails, especially on Mission 4. I could improve by doing more explicit Merlin-baiting as Morgana to confuse Percival and by shaping a clearer narrative earlier about who I trusted, to better steer votes and suspicions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very strong, low-key Mordred game, staying trusted enough to be repeatedly selected while slipping a key fail on Mission 3 and blending perfectly into the good team narrative.
player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and seemed risk-averse, not pushing strong accusations, which made them look generally good but also meant they didn’t strongly drive the table’s logic.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, came off as unpredictable and somewhat detached from the core logic, which created noise but didn’t clearly signal alignment either way.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, appeared to be actively reading signals but didn’t successfully distinguish between Merlin and Morgana, which helped evil stay hidden and protected Frank.
player_observations.Eve: Played like a straightforward good, consistently choosing teams that looked reasonable from a surface perspective, which made her appear trustworthy but also a bit readable.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, did excellent subtle steering—he avoided obvious hard calls while still guiding team selections enough that good often looked reasonable, though he ultimately wasn’t protected from evil’s win.
